results.content: I wasted a lot of time with the ssl.  Even though when started the visual studio solution I checked the ignore certificates options.  Yet PostMan didn't work until some how I got an ignore certificates message from that - not even sure how I got it.  Then when you had parameters for put and delete, it looked like you were still using the postman body to pass them, and took awhile for me to realize the id for put and delete should be in the postman url.  I'm still not sure what is the deal with parameters in the [HttpGet] what their real purpose is, as it seems like you don't need them.  And my final question of how much overloading can you do with the Get,Post,Put and Delete.  And how would you audit log all your database changes.

There are two versions of the course here, the old version and the updated version (which goes to section 13). I missed some concepts that were covered in the old version but not in the updated one, like dependency injection and versioning. I also missed a summary at the end of the updated version. Also, as a non native, I struggled a bit with the lack of captions that were not auto-generated, I feel it would be a nice addition to the course.

results.content: If you are familiar with C # and have programming skills, the course is easy to understand. There are two small negative points. First the volume changes between some sections / modules and secondly, personally, I would sometimes prefer that the lesson delves a little deeper into the subject. For example, how to use swagger with MediaType API versioning.  For an introduction to the topic, however, is completely sufficient.

results.content:
Really confusing, is the key here! I advise only if you are an experienced programmer. If your goal is to learn some theory about REST & RESTful, this is not the course. There is no programming pattern, the project files and content change from video to video without any explanation, and it is up to you to try and figure out what happened. 

The guy knows what he is talking about, be he is not prepared to teach. 

I was surprised on how little this is focused on REST & RESTful, it is more a asp.net core intensive course. In this course only 5 HTTP Verbs were covered, really disappointed here.

results.content:
UPDATE for 2021 edition.  I changed my 3 star rating to 5 stars because of the 2021 course.  I highly recommend this course to anyone that needs to learn what is listed in the course description.  The course material is clearly explained and has good examples.  The only thing missing with the new material is versioning, it is available in the old material though (section 25: versioning).

Original review (3 stars), which now starts at Section 17: Introduction
The course can be worth taking to get an overview of the basics.  There are no other courses specifically for learning REST in .NET CORE so it is this or a different website.  I had a few issues.  The instructor frequently rushes and at times the video speed is obviously faster than normal.  It would have been nice if he made the course 30 minutes longer.  I had to use Google to find answers on why my solution didn't build when his did.  A few times I noticed code was added that he didn't discuss, nothing major but it was annoying.  Other times the video cuts go from no code to having code without mentioning it.  He also has an accent that can be hard to understand when he talks too fast.  The transcript is not helpful in these cases, it was not updated by a person so it understands the instructor less than I do.  Here are 2 examples:
1. Well it was the task of back in December and he really to take it off the medications.
2. In addition Well data in that dark that means add extra meaning to the data by any edible decks.

results.content:
I would only recommend this course for the very absolute beginner. If you have any experience with C#/.NET, I feel you'd have a better experience by reading the documentation and tutorials provided by Microsoft. If you are an absolute beginner, and would rather watch than read, then this course may be fine.

From a technical perspective, there's some features that were left out around .NET Core. Also the audio fluctuated between almost every video where I was constantly turning up or down the volume. If you have any use for subtitles, they are completely wrong and off on almost every video and I would not recommend using them at all.
